sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1:
Determine the standard enthalpy change for the reaction:   
Fe2O3 (s) + 3CO (g) → 2Fe (s) + 3CO2 (g)

given the following values of standard enthalpy of formation:

ΔHf° [Fe2O3 (s)] = -824 kJ/mol  
ΔHf° [CO2 (g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol  
ΔHf° [CO (g)] = -110.5 kJ/mol  
ΔHf° [Fe (s)] = 0 kJ/mol
message_2:
To determine the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the products:
2 mol Fe (s) and 3 mol CO2 (g)
ΔHf°(products) = (2 × 0 kJ/mol) + (3 × -393.5 kJ/mol) = -1180.5 kJ/mol

For the reactants:
1 mol Fe2O3 (s) and 3 mol CO (g)
ΔHf°(reactants) = (-824 kJ/mol) + (3 × -110.5 kJ/mol) = -1155.5 kJ/mol

Now, we can calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction:

ΔH°(reaction) = (-1180.5 kJ/mol) - (-1155.5 kJ/mol) = -25 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -25 kJ/mol.
